awd_titl_txt: US Participation at the Twenty-sixth International Domain Decomposition Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
Since 1987, the International Conferences of Domain Decomposition Methods (DDM) have been held in 15 countries throughout Asia, Europe and North America. The 27th edition of this prestigious conference will be held at the Czech Technical University in Prague, Czech Republic, on July 25-29, 2022. The primary topic of the conference concerns large scale scientific computing problems, which are an important and very general interdisciplinary research field and plays a crucial role in many application areas, for example weather forecast, seismic predictions, fluid simulations, material industry, oil field exploration, medical imaging, among others. This project will enable US based junior researchers to travel to the conference, network, and present their research.

The International Conference of Domain Decomposition Methods is the only regularly occurring international forum dedicated to interdisciplinary technical interactions between theoreticians and practitioners working in the development, analysis, software implementation, and application of domain decomposition methods, which are important in scientific computing. The complexity and size of such problems often lead to very large systems, where massive computing resources and special computational approaches must be employed to obtain approximate solutions. As we approach the dawn of exascale computing, scalable techniques such as DDM are vital tools for solving complex problems that would otherwise be intractable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided funding for junior US researchers to attend a highly acclaimed internation conference on domain decomposition methods which was held in Prague in 2022. Domain decomposition methods are a class of algorithms used to model physical phenomena by dividing the physical domain into smaller pieces, modelling the phenomenon on each smaller piece (which is usually much easier), and then pasting these solutions together again. The mathematics involved in doing this properly is fairly involved and there is much active research on improving the efficiency, scalability, stability, and accuracy of domain decomposition methods. One of the primary applications of domain decomposition methods is in solid mechanics, where one simulates the behavior of solid materials under different stresses. Utilizing domain decomposition methods has resulted in the development of software which enables larger scale and more efficient simulation of such physical systems. This, in turn, has resulted in improvements in a variety of engineering fields, since understanding the behavior of solid materials under stress is critical in building infrastructure such as bridges, roads, buildings, power plants, etc. The opportunity for US researchers to attend this conference on domain decomposition methods has enabled them to disseminate their own research findings, which improves the standing of the US in the field, and also to learn from other researchers, which allows them to bring their newfound knowledge back to the US and improve our technology. Thus, by enabling these researchers to attend the conference on domain decomposition methods, we have indirectly improved the US technology surrounding structural engineering and other related disciplines. Moreover, the mathematics behind scientific computing, which is widely used in essentially all engineering disciplines, is highly interrelated so that advances in the field of domain decomposition methods indirectly lead to improvements in other areas. This includes areas as diverse as weather forecasting and building nuclear weapons.
